I've been playing this game for several years and I think I have a pretty good grip now on orbital mechanics, i.e. I can predict how the shape of any orbit is going to change with a burn in any direction, and vice versa.

However I still struggle with predicting what the result of gravitational assists in encounters is going to be. Recently this has led to situations like this http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/132476-help-get-jeb-and-bill-home/

I have given it some thought and come up with some rules of thumb to help predict what affects can be achieved with an assist manoeuvre.

Are these correct and can anyone add anything else helpful?

  1. An encounter will either add or remove speed from a spacecraft as measured in the parent SOI just before entering and just after and leaving the assisting SOI.
  2. More massive, and faster moving bodies are capable of larger effects and passing closer to them will increase the effect.
  3. Whether you get an accelerating or braking affect depends on the angle that the incoming orbit makes to the assisting body vs the angle the outgoing orbit makes to the assisting orbit. If the incoming angle is larger than the outgoing angle you get an accelerating assist, if smaller a braking assist.
  4. The difference between the angles is proportional to the size of the effect.
  5. Everything in KSP that you are going to get a meaningful assist from is moving a an orbit that is close enough to circular to make little difference.
  6. A braking assist will always lower you PE
  7. An accelerating assist will always raise your AP

I feel there is also a rule about a braking assist always increasing the eccentricity of an orbit but I can think of an exception when capturing from a hyperbolic orbit and I'm not sure if it is true otherwise.

Relevant article : 

http://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/2013/20130926-gravity-assist.html?referrer=http://space.stackexchange.com/questions/9504/how-can-i-intuitively-understand-gravity-assists

It's a little long, but really nicely explains how and why they work. From what I understand about it, nothing in your 'rules' contradict that article.

There's also the KSP-specific "SOI effect". Because the major body's gravity doesn't affect your vessel while you're in a minor body's SOI, you are effectively plucked out of the major SOI at a given altitude with a given ratio of kinetic-to-potential energy, and dropped back into it at a different altitude with a different kinetic-to-potential ratio.

So even if the minor body changes virtually nothing to your trajectory, the mere fact of disappearing from the major SOI at one altitude (and therefore with a given potential energy) and reappearing at another (with higher, or lower potential energy, depending on whether at a higher or lower altitude) will necessarily increase (or decrease) the total orbital energy of your vessel.

This gives a rule of thumb (all other things being equal) of: if you are falling towards the major body, you will be slowed. If you are rising, you will speed up.

The thing that helps me visualize the effects of gravity assists is to remember that gravity assists are just substitutes for some or all of a conventional burn.  Therefore, you need to set your course so that you pass through a point analogous to where you'd do a conventional burn for the desired effect in the absence of having gravity to help.

I think #3 is more correctly stated as follows:  To get a braking effect, pass the assisting body on the side facing its parent body.  To get an accelerating effect, pass the assisting body on the side away from its parent.

I would also restate #4 as follows:  The size of the assist you get in either direction depends on 3 main factors:

  1. The mass of the assisting body.  The greater the mass, the greater the effect.
  2. The altitude of your Pe at the assisting body.  The lower your Pe, the greater the effect.
  3. The angle between your ship's path and the assisting body's orbit.  The closer your ship's path is to being tangential to the assisting body's orbit, the greater the effect in terms of scalar speed change and the less change in your vector direction.  OTOH, the closer your ship's path is to being perpendicular to the assisting body's orbit, the less scalar speed change and the greater the vector direction change.

I would also add a new rule #4.1 as follows:  For braking assists off moons intended to aid in capturing around the main planet from interplanetary transfer orbits the significance of the braking depends not only on the above factors but also on the distance of the moon from the main planet.  Using Mun to help return to Kerbin, or using Tylo or Laythe to help capture into Jool orbit can significantly reduce the burn needed to capture at the parent.  However, in OPM, Slate, despite being pretty much the same as Tylo, is too far from Sarnus to be of any real help.  Because your Sarnus Pe after passing Slate is so high, you end up burning just as much fuel to capture at Sarnus as if you'd just burned at the lowest safe Sarnus Pe to begin with.

My experience with gravity assists in KSP is pretty much limited to interplanetary capture assists as noted above, plus using Eve to help get to Moho on the cheap.  I have only ever used an acceleration assist to achieve Kerbol-escape velocity.  This is because the KSP solar system is so small that it's pretty easy to carry enough fuel to go wherever you want without having to rely on gravity assists, and this also avoids the complexity of trying to figure out when the planets align for a Voyager-style series of assists.

I don't think you make much net change in your energy, you more change its direction.  Say you're in an eccentric orbit around Kerbin with an Ap somewhere beyond Mun.  If you come in making a "behind-and-inside" pass by Mun on your way towards your Kerbin Pe, and this ends up making  you depart Mun's SO( more parallel with Mun's orbit, what you've done there is raised your Kerbin Pe some.  You'd think that's adding energy but it's balanced by this being a braking maneuver due to it being a retrograde pass.  Thus, it's pulling down your Kerbin Ap at the same time, so you end up in a more circular orbit, higher Kerbin Pe, lower Kerbin Ap.

I think what you're desribing is where KSP breaks with real life, because of the "SOI effect" I desribed above.

Come from a higher angle above the Mun to a more parallel angle to the Mun's orbit should IRL add a significant amount of energy to your vessel. However, you are being plucked out of Kerbin's SOI at a given potential energy and dropped at a lower potential energy. The kinetic energy you gained by being propelled along the Mun's orbit is effectively negated by the SOI effect. IRL, Kerbin would continue to accelerate you towards the planet even whie you were being dragged around the Mun, but in KSP it can't do that.

It could be.  In fact, that could be the major factor involved.  But I still think that even without the "Plusck Effect",the scenario described by @tomf above would have a net loss of energy because it involves a retrograde pass by Mun, just not much due to crossing Mun's orbit at a steep angle.  There is, however, a major change of direction.  So it's more of an evening out of the orbital energy instead of having all the potential at Ap and all the kinetic at Pe in the original elliptical orbit.

The scenario I mentioned can have a very significant accelerating effect. For an orbit around kerbin with pe=70k and ap = 53,000k (just outside Minmus). That will cross the Mun's SOI at about 677m/s at an angle of 15 degrees for a relative velocity of 746 m/s. If we can deflect the orbit by enough, passing behind and inside the mun we could return to kerbin's orbit with a velocity of 1289ms (746 + the Mun's 542) which is easily an escape velocity and will get you out to Duna

The article given by FullMetalMachinist is really quite excellent, and the 3x3 grid gif itself is great: http://planetary.s3.amazonaws.com/assets/images/charts-diagrams/20130925_Fig2-assist-gallery.gif.  On that gif there is only a 90° turn about the minor body (not the 115° described by tomf) so the situation we're talking about is similar to an incoming angle of "h" and outgoing angle of "f" - clearly a boost from the major body's point of view in any event.

I certainly wouldn't use my nick for the SOI-effect - I'm certainly not the only one to have deduced it's existence. However if tomf can give the formula I asked for above, it can certainly be quantified: you just need to work out the velocity of a craft descending towards Kerbin from a 70km/53000km orbit at the edge of the Mun's SOI (12,000km + 2,400km or so), then what the velocity should have been at the altitude of the Mun itself (12,000km) if it hadn't entered the Mun's SOI, and the difference is the "potential" velocity that has been lost due to entering the SOI from a higher altitude and exiting at a lower one. In the given example, I would suspect it isn't all that much, and certainly not enough to counter the over-542m/s boost that a such a large change in trajectory would give the ship.

I Hadn't taken the Plusk effect into account previously so I have just added it to my spreadsheet, you enter the Mun's SOI at a kerbin height of 144Mm and leave at 120Mm and the difference is negligible. the change's in velocity at SOI boundaries are entirely predictable and taken into account. The thing that is pretty unrealistic is that the Mun slingshot has it's PE well inside its crust.

 

 

A more realistic PE of 8km will only get you a boost of 371m/s which will still get you half way to Duna

I think I was too hasty in agreeing with you earlier. ; )

But the problem is, those numbers are based on a constant frame of reference, all measured relative to a body other than the one you're gravity-surfing on.  KSP doesn't work that way.  Every time you change SOI, the frame of reference changes to the body owning the SOI.  This changes both the magnitude and direction of the ship's velocity, often quite significantly and in defiance of all logic.

A simple example:  a normal transfer to Mun to capture into a prograde orbit where you cross Mun's orbit slightly before the encounter.  On the map view just prior to the encounter, while you're in Kerbin's SOI, you're moving at a few thousand m/s and heading in a prograde orbital direction with Mun behind and inside of you.  Keep the map focused on your ship and oriented so you can see both Kerbin and Mun.  Then boom, you cross into Mun's SOI.  Your ship, Mun, and Kerbin don't move.  However, your ship changes direction by about 135^ to be heading back at Mun, and its speed now is only few hundred m/s.  Now, you might argue that this is just a display thing and that somewhere, the game is keeping track of the ship's position and velocity based on some fixed, universal coordinate system, so all this really makes no significant difference.  But how solid is that assumption?

Consider the classic "Joolian Snooker" problem of trying to transfer from Laythe to Vall as efficiently as you can, so you leave Laythe tangential to its orbit and meet Vall on the opposite side of Jool from where you left Laythe.  So you do this burn in Laythe's SOI and achieve Laythe escape velocity in the same direction Laythe is moving.  While within Laythe's SOI, you are moving considerably faster than Laythe so leave it behind, eventually exiting its SOI and entering Jool's.

Now logically, because you've left Laythe's SOI and are moving faster than it, you just go on about your business.  And in fact the map view reflects this, showing clear sailing all the way to Vall.  But you're now in Jool's SOI and must play by its rules.  From Jool's POV, you are now moving only slightly faster than Laythe, and as you climb out towards Vall you're slowing down.  It doesn't take long for your speed relative to Jool to drop below Laythe's, which means Laythe is now catching up with you from behind.  And because you're on an efficient, low-angle transfer trajectory, you're not moving outwards from Laythe's orbit very fast.  Thus, by the time Laythe catches up with you, you haven't moved far enough outwards to be out of reach of its SOI.  The result:  suddenly, without any warning on the map view or even from KAC if you have that, you're back in Laythe's SOI.  And you're heading in the opposite direction, back at Laythe, usually on a collision course, and with a very high velocity relative to Laythe.  Hope you had a quicksave from before you burned, so you can redo the burn for a less-efficient transfer going outwards faster.

Granted, this is something of an extreme example, but it shows that the game's left hand doesn't know what it's right hand is doing.  The part of the game you interact with as a player is telling you all is well and playing by logical rules.  However, the part of the game that actually matters, the one actually controls the position and velocity of your ship, is playing by its own bizarre set of rules.  The bottom line is that the map view lies to you, there doesn't seem to be any universal coordinate system in use by what actually moves your ship, and you can't make exact calculations, or even very tight estimates, across SOI boundaries.

So, there are real orbital mechanics, which the map view tries hard to show you, and there are KSP orbital mechanics, which is what really happens.  For conventional burns not using gravity assists, the results are very similar---otherwise, KSP wouldn't be a viable product.  But the whole SOI thing contains a major flaw somewhere, the effects of which are exacerbated in certain situations to produce wildly divergent results from what you expect to happen from the map view.  It seems to me that trying to do radical gravity assists is one of these situations.

@Plusck My latest version of the spreadsheet I used to work these numbers out no longer has 677 as the velocity of the Mun encounter, the value taking into effect the Mun's SOI is now 654.

That is an application of the Vis-viva equation v^2=GM(2/r-1/a) with a=53600000 and r= 12.7Mm which is the kerbin radius where we encounter the moon

GM is the standard gravitation parameter for a body or μ which comes from the wiki pages. In real physics μ is known for most bodies much more accurately than either G or M.

No really, it is easy to take all this into account. When you transition from Kerbin's SOI int the Mun's SOI KSP simply subtracts the vector of the Mun's velocity from your velocity.

In a transfer orbit from low Kerbin orbit ->Mun you will be traveling at 176m/s when you encounter the Mun coming up at 542m/s behind you. Your relative velocity is 366 m/s and that is the Mun centric velocity that will be displayed. (transfer pe=670km and ap=12Mm (from kerbin centre) and encountering Mun exactly at AP. If your encounter is earlier or later the figures will be slightly different)

The thing you described with Laythe is noothing to do with the maths not being correct, it is simply that KSP won't show you a future encounter with the body that you are already orbiting.

I was going to snip some of that to save space, but there's actually nothing to cut out since it's all good.

Apart from "This changes both the magnitude and direction of the ship's velocity, often quite significantly and in defiance of all logic."
I think the whole thing about orbital mechanics is that it defies logic because it defies intuitive logic until you've had enough time to think about it. It's one of the great things about the game: it forces the player to get to grips with notions that a number of respected physicists and engineers had a great deal of problem with before they were demonstrated to be true.

However, I think people have different ways of dealing with orbital interactions that start off by seeming "against all logic". My "Aha!" moment came when I realised I wasn't looking at moons and planets as being moving points, but vast moving spheres representing their SOI. That's where your Laythe-to-Vall problem starts looking very obvious: you are leaving a vast sphere from the middle, then slowing down as you climb towards the top of that sphere. Slow down faster than the gradient of that virtual mountain coming up on you (imagine you're in a plane taking off in a crosswind, with a huge hill on the downwind side that you need to climb over before you get blown into it... it sorta does that for me) and you get caught badly.

So yes, the map lies to you. I absolutely agree. And I keep planning to produce a bunch of pictures for a tutorial of sorts (basically a continuation of the pic I posted here:

... which was actually spurred by my own thoughts about incoming vs outgoing angles when encountering another SOI, which I hadn't quite managed to reduce to a rule of thumb like tomf's rule #3.
